I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the assistance of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) during the country programming mission in July 2003, to 
support  the  China  Banking  Regulatory  Commission  (CBRC)  in  improving  its  capacity  to 
supervise foreign banking organizations (FBOs) in the PRC. The Fact-Finding mission visited 
the PRC in September 2003 and reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government on the 
objectives,  scope,  cost,  financing,  and  implementation  arrangements  for  the  technical 
assistance (TA). The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 1 
  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  As an integral part of the banking sector reforms, the PRC Government has opened up 
its banking market to FBOs by gradually removing barriers to entry. Although FBOs have had a 
presence in the PRC since 1949, 2 they were not allowed to engage in local currency business 
until 1996. In 1998, 3 selected FBOs were for the first time allowed to participate in domestic 
currency interbank lending and to gradually expand their geographical outreach. Attracted by 
the increasing demand from foreign enterprises in the PRC and the PRC’s strong economic 
growth potential, FBOs rapidly increased the number of their branches4 to 157 by October 2003.  
 
3.  CBRC  was  established  in  April  20035 to  assume  the  regulatory  and  supervisory 
functions of financial institutions from the central bank, the People’s Bank of China (PBC). This 
step was taken to draw a line between banking supervision and monetary policy in order to 
prevent PBC from using banking supervision as a tool of monetary policy by way of liquidity 
control and access. CBRC is responsible for supervising PRC branches and agencies of FBOs 
as  well  as  domestic  commercial  banks  and  nonbank  financial  institutions.  The  main 
responsibilities of CBRC are to (i) issue regulations and provide regulatory guidelines related to 
financial institutions; (ii) examine and approve the establishment, abolishment, and modification 
of financial institutions, their branches, and their scope of business; and (iii) conduct on-site and 
off-site supervision of financial institutions based on laws, regulations, published manuals, and 
internal  guidelines  and  procedures.  CBRC  has  regional  offices  in  each  of  36  provinces, 
autonomous regions, and municipalities. The head office and regional offices engage in the 
supervisory activities for FBOs. 
 
4.  Under the PRC’s World Trade Organization (WTO) accession requirements, the PRC 
will open its banking market by gradually removing its restrictions on FBOs’ activities. FBOs— 
which were allowed to engage in foreign currency business with Chinese enterprises and 
individuals at the time of the PRC’s accession to WTO—will be allowed to engage in local 
currency services for domestic enterprises by December 2003, and for domestic individuals by 
December 2006. FBOs’ geographic restrictions have also been gradually removed and will be 
completely abolished by 2006. This, combined with expected strong economic growth, is likely 
to cause a surge of FBO activities in the PRC over the next few years. Importantly, the more

5.   Although FBOs’ activities will  have a positive impact on the PRC’s banking sector, 
unless properly supervised, FBOs’ increasing activities in the PRC could increase systemic risk 
in the banking sector. FBOs will prove to be important players in the PRC’s banking market6 — 
FBOs will start to make local currency loans to domestic enterprises in December 2003 and to 
collect local currency deposits from domestic individuals in 2006. Thus, the PRC authorities 
must effectively supervise FBO branches to ensure the soundness of the PRC’s banking system. 
 
6.  Foreign licensed financial institutions have occasionally violated domestic regulations— 
e.g., Barings in Singapore, Daiwa Bank in New York, and Credit Swiss in Tokyo—showing that 
a sophisticated financial institution based in a well regulated financial market is not free from risk. 
The failure to adequately regulate foreign affiliates is a common feature of all these cases and, 
in some circumstances, the lack of internal procedures in banks to ensure compliance with 
domestic regulations and lack of appropriate information sharing between home and host 
supervisor7 made matters worse. A supervisory framework needs to be developed for FBOs, 
especially a framework to effectively assess, evaluate, and monitor the risk management, 
internal control, and compliance of FBOs and to cooperate and share information between 
home and host supervisors. This will mitigate the risk and help ensure the soundness of the 
financial markets in both host and home countries. 
 
7.  The rapid progress in financing techniques and risk management systems in commercial 
banks requires the strengthening of the banking supervision in the PRC and elsewhere. The 
loan migration model for credit risk management used in commercial banks in developed 
economies  is  a  challenge  that  regulators  face  in  assessing  the  validity  of  banks’  risk 
management systems. Many foreign banks operating in host countries use these technologies 
to increase profit and manage risk. Assessing risk management systems requires especially 
well-trained and highly skilled regulators. 
 
8.  The PRC has been relying mainly on capital requirements and restrictions on the scope 
of business activities and geographical areas to manage  FBO activities. These regulatory 
measures are inadequate to mitigate risk in FBOs. Recognizing this constraint, the newly 
established CBRC is seeking to adopt a risk-based supervisory framework focused on internal 
control for FBO branches. 
 
9.  The PRC’s accession to WTO will encourage a  change in supervision of FBOs. The 
restrictions on the scope of business and geographical area will be abolished by 2006. Other 
regulations of FBOs’ business activities will be  reviewed to ensure equal treatment between 
domestic banks and FBOs. The abolition or modification of existing supervisory tools demands 
that a new framework be designed to effectively supervise the activities of FBOs in the PRC.  
 
10.  The existing internal procedures and published supervisory manuals of CBRC are not 
sufficiently  comprehensive  to  effectively  assess,  evaluate,  and  monitor  either  domestic  or

Regarding the prospect of FBOs’ market share in the future (2010–2015), there are a wide variety of estimates

7  “Home supervisors” refers to the banking supervisory authorities of the countries where the head office of the FBO 
is located, and “host supervisors” refers to the banking supervisory authorities of the countries where foreign 
branches of the FBOs are located.

3 
foreign banking organizations. Although the quality of supervisory activities has improved by 
establishing these procedures and manuals, CBRC needs further strengthening. CBRC needs a 
modern supervisory framework by which it can comprehensively evaluate and identify weaker 
areas of banks. CBRC also needs a mechanism for sharing information among its regional 
offices. FBOs need to understand the supervisory procedures, which can be arranged through 
published CBRC operations manuals. Many domestic banks need improvements in internal 
control and/or risk management systems and effective supervision by CBRC will contribute to 
the improvements. 
 
11.  As a first step, CBRC envisages establishing a comprehensive supervisory framework 
for the PRC branches of FBOs. CBRC has started preparatory and drafting works for a new 
supervisory  framework  for  FBOs,  including  manuals,  guidelines,  and  a  supervisory  rating 
system. However, consultation with international experts and training opportunities for CBRC 
staff are necessary to fully assimilate the practices in other countries and make the new 
framework  effective  and  consistent  with  the  best  international  practices.  Therefore,  the 
Government requested ADB assistance for the establishment of a new supervisory framework 
for FBOs. 
 
12.  The PRC Government is also strengthening its supervision of domestic banks. PBC 
published guidelines on commercial banks’ internal control in 2002. CBRC is now establishing 
guidelines on credit risk management of commercial banks. The draft guidelines emphasize the 
importance of the internal control structure. Although these guidelines are an important first step 
toward  risk-based  and  internal-control-focused  supervision,  more  will  have  to  be  done  to 
establish a comprehensive framework. As many FBOs are expected to have an effective 
internal  risk  management  system  and  internal  control  practice,  CBRC’s  experience  in 
supervision of FBOs will help the regulatory agency upgrade its capacities in supervising 
domestic banks. 
 
13.  ADB has been supporting the Government’s efforts in reforming its financial sector, 
strengthening  banking  supervision,  and  facilitating  its  complete  integration  into  the  global 
financial  market  through  several  projects,  such  as  Banking  Laws  and  Regulations,8 and 
Strengthening Banking Supervision and Liquidity Risk Management. 9 ADB’s strategy in the 
PRC Country Strategy and Program Update 2003–2005 emphasizes improvement of banking 
supervision and  strengthening of banking management with specific focus on WTO-related 
issues. Assistance for the establishment of an effective framework to supervise FBOs will 
reduce the risks arising from FBOs’ activities in the PRC, expedite the reduction of existing 
restrictions  on  FBOs,  facilitate  FBOs’  activities  in  the  PRC,  and  improve  the  institutional 
capabilities of CBRC in assessing, evaluating, and monitoring banks’ risk management, internal 
control, and compliance.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
14.  The objectives of the TA are to (i) establish an effective supervisory framework for FBOs 
while not undermining the equal opportunities for foreign and domestic banks, in particular, to 
devise appropriate methodologies for evaluating FBO branches by assessing and monitoring

4 
their risk management, internal control, and compliance; and (ii) strengthen CBRC’s capacity to 
effectively supervise FBOs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will undertake specific activities in following areas: 
 
(i)  establish an effective supervisory framework for FBOs comprising 
(a)  a supervisory rating system to evaluate the risk levels and identify weak 
areas, 
(b)  a supervisory information system to share information between CBRC 
staffs in regional offices, 
(c)  streamlining of supervision activities according to the risk level, 
(d)  supervision manuals and guidelines for on-site and off-site supervision, 
and 
(e)  a  mechanism  for  cooperation  and  information  sharing  with  home 
supervisors based on the best international practices prescribed by the 
Basel Committee documents;10 and  
 
(ii)  improve the capacity of CBRC staff in banking supervision by 
(a)  disseminating  the  new  supervisory  framework  through  seminars  and 
workshops, and 
(b)  organizing domestic and overseas training program for staff of CBRC. 
 
C.        Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $550,000 equivalent comprising  a foreign 
exchange cost of $310,000 and a local currency cost of $240,000 equivalent. The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $400,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost 
and $90,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will finance the local 
currency cost, equivalent to $150,000 through the provision of counterpart staff, office space, 
and contingencies. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The 
detailed cost estimates and financing plan of the TA are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.        Implementation Arrangements 
17.  CBRC’s Banking Supervision Department III (BSD3) will be  the Executing Agency.  A 
working group will be established, under the leadership of the director general of BSD3, to work 
as counterparts of the consultants and ensure the successful implementation of the TA. CBRC 
will provide necessary office space, counterpart staff, and other facilities to the consultants and 
will arrange appointments for the consultants with relevant agencies and organizations. 
 
18.  The TA will engage international consultants for a total of 6 person-months: (i) one risk-
based banking supervision specialist and team leader (3.5 person-months) who has practical 
experience with on-site inspections and supervisory rating systems and in-depth knowledge of 
banks’  risk  management  and  internal  control  systems;  and  (ii)  one  cross-border banking

supervision specialist (2.5 person-months) who has practical experience in supervision for 
FBOs, and in-depth knowledge of (a) the procedures for cooperating and information sharing 
with foreign supervisors, (b) available information sources for FBOs, (c) the Basel Committee’s 
documents related to cross-border banking supervision, and (d) supervisory information system 
for FBOs. The TA will also engage a domestic consultant (banking regulation specialist) for a 
total of 6 person-months. The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The 
consultants will be selected and engaged as individual consultants in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement of domestic consultants. 
 
19.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report 3 weeks after commencement of 
their services, (ii) monthly interim progress reports during TA implementation, (iii) a draft final 
report  before  the  conclusion  of  the  contract,  and  (iv)  the  final  report  two  weeks  after, 
incorporating BSD3’s and ADB’s comments. The TA will commence in February 2004 and be 
completed in September 2004. Seminars and workshops will be organized intermittently during 
the implementation period to invite comments from international and domestic experts in the 
field and disseminate the findings of the TA. Short-term overseas training will be organized 
during the implementation period to provide BSD3 staff an opportunity to learn actual practices 
of risk-based supervision for FBOs in other countries. An advance payment facility  will be 
instituted to support the Government in organizing the domestic seminars and the overseas 
training visits. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.    The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  a  Foreign  Bank  Rating  and  Risk 
Management System, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (6 person-months) 
 
1.  Team Leader and Risk-based Banking Supervision Specialist (3.5 person-
months) 
1.   As the team leader, the consultant will be responsible for the overall management of 
technical assistance implementation, timely delivery of quality interim and final reports, and 
recruitment and management of resource persons for technical tasks. As the risk-based banking 
supervision specialist, he or she will be primarily responsible for assisting China Banking 
Regulatory Commission (CBRC) staff with practical knowledge in risk-based supervision and 
organizing training activities. Specifically, the specialist will 
 
(i)  assess the supervisory framework of CBRC and identify issues that need to be 
addressed in the move toward a banking supervisory framework that is risk-
based and internal-control-focused, according to the best international practices; 
 
(ii)  help develop the ROCA1 rating system and provide recommendations to CBRC 
on its coverage and supervisory rating methodologies,  with specific focus on 
measures to 
 
(a)  quantify the results of supervisory evaluation in each check point within a 
supervisory category in deriving a synthesized rating through appropriate 
weighting within that category according to size, complexity, and business 
scope of foreign banking organizations (FBOs); 
(b)  incorporate the ratings in each category into a comprehensive rating of 
the FBO branches; and 
(c)  identify and confirm the weak areas and risks of FBO branches combining 
the results from various supervisory methods; 
 
(iii)  recommend how to use the results of the supervisory rating system as a strategy 
for the next rounds of supervisory activities, including 
 
(a)  the frequency of on-site inspections according to the levels of risk, 
(b)  the methodologies and procedures for special advice or requirement for 
FBO branches to improve in weaknesses, and 
(c)  legal  and  regulatory  requirements  to  ensure  a  proper  legal  basis  for 
supervisory actions aforementioned in (iiib); 
 
(iv)  in the context of adopting risk-based supervision, help draft and improve existing 
drafts of CBRC’s internal guidelines and procedures (GPs) for on-site and off-site 
supervision for branches of FBOs, with the particular focus on 
 
(a)  establishing  proper  objectives  of  inspections  in  the  category  of  risk 
management, internal control, and compliance;

(v)  help draft CBRC’s operations manuals, which is an abbreviated version of the

GPs; 
(b)  assess the validity of loan migration models used in advanced FBOs for

(vii)  organize  short  overseas  training  for  selected  CBRC  staff  to  enhance  their 
understanding of the supervision practices in other countries; and 
 
(viii)  recommend areas of further work and development in risk-based supervision 
framework with specific focus on the items and steps necessary to adopt a 
similar framework to the supervision for domestic banks. 
 
2.  Cross-Border Banking Supervision Specialist (2.5 person-months) 
2.  In consultation with the risk-based bank supervision specialist, the consultant take the 
lead in tasks regarding cross-border banking supervision issues that affects FBOs, including 
 
(i)  analyzing CBRC’s current  supervisory framework for FBO branches to clarify 
cross-border issues that need to be addressed, and develop a plan to move 
toward  risk-based  and  internal-control-focused  supervisory  means while not 
undermining the equal opportunities among foreign and domestic banks; 
 
(ii)  recommending measures to establish a mechanism for CBRC to cooperate and 
to  share  information  with  home  supervisors  of  FBOs  based  on  the  best

B.  Domestic Consultant (6 person-months) 
 
3.  A domestic banking regulation  specialist will be recruited to assist the international 
consultants. The domestic consultant will assist the international consultants to quickly become 
familiarized  with  their  tasks  by  translating  documents  between  Chinese  and  English; 
researching and compiling a set of government practices, regulations, and procedures adopted; 
ensuring that the work of the international consultants is appropriate for the PRC situation; and 
coordinating with other government agencies and stakeholders. The domestic consultant is 
expected to possess sufficient knowledge and experience in banking activities and related laws 
and regulations for the completion of the above tasks. 
 
C.  Reports
